newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian rupee ends up vs dlr despite RBI buying.
newsitem.headline: Indian rupee ends up vs dlr despite RBI buying.

text.p: The Indian rupee ended Tuesday at 35.75/76 per dollar, up from opening quotes of 35.76/77 despite Reserve Bank of India (RBI) intervention, dealers said.
They said the rupee shrugged off central bank intervention and moved up after dipping briefly to 35.78.
"The RBI intervention was not enough to hold the rupee back," said a dealer at a foreign bank. "It (RBI) was briefly in the market in early interbank trade, buying dollars between 35.76 and 35.77."
Dealers said the RBI intervened as the rupee was looking to move up through the 35.75 mark.
They said the rupee traded at a high of 35.75 and a low of 35.78 on Tuesday and that 35.76-35.7650 was the most actively traded range.
Dealers said poor dollar demand was the prime reason behind the rupee's strength and said the rupee was unlikely to weaken unless import demand picked up.
"That (import demand) will be the key factor," said a dealer at a satte-run bank. "Unless that picks up, even small inflows will push the rupee up."
In the forward market, premiums continued to fall on a combination of poor demand, good domestic liquidity and expectations of low interest rates.
Dealers said the rupee ended up against the forward dollar after dropping in morning trade.
"There was some buying of forward dollars when the RBI hit the spot market," said a dealer. "October dollars went up 90 paise but selling at higher levels soon brough the rupee back."
October-delivery dollars were quoted at a premium of 84/86 paise against opening quotes of 88/91.
